review_title: Hopeless and dangerous to work for
pros: Was the pay but made staff take a pay cut in 8th January! Nights team earn pound an hour less days team also but on weekends earn only £2.00 an hour more than national and that is 14 hours days. Despite a cost of living crisis even though CEO has £95,000 a year salary in a recent Guardian newspaper article of charity bosses pay.
cons: Morale for permanent staff rock bottom. Agency paid more and work less meaning sickness and leaving of staff is a constant issue. Management including Deputy Managers who are nurses and a manager who is not don't give annual leave and carers leave and expect people to work during their annual leave or days off at short notice while they swan off on long haul holidays. Staff have to plead for time off it is Dickensian workhouse conditions. PPE is not used aprons fall on shower floors in patients bedrooms bundled in a ball no hooks and gloves are thin clear plastic from food handling not proper barrier clothing. Needless to say Covid and stomach bugs are rampant as mops are never cleaned either reused on floors again and again. A them and us mentality of juvenile bullying occurs within the staff team. Nothing is done when you raise issues. Dangerous work practices including no manual handling or risk assessments shown to staff new or agency before using equipment for transfer and broken equipment information not handed over to next shift and untested eqipment told to be used by nurse leads to carers equipment that is not suitable for bariatic patients who weigh over the maximum load. Diet is appalling of residents hardly any fruit or fibre or fish and veg all white bread and processed food. NO team or staff meetings just get on with your job. Progression within organisation is not encouraged or advertised.

job_title: Support Worker in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: It's the best job there is especially looking after the people who use our service. It a lovely atmosphere. You get to have a fun with a lot of people and also we treat every people who your our service eqaully valued to all the people. There is no such things as different we are all the same. This is why we have activities everyday we so that people has the capacity to enjoy themselves and great staff to work get them involved in any activities every day basis. I also love giving the people of looking after them with the great of respect and dignity. We staff work as a team. This is why I loved working with Leonard Cheshire Disability.
cons: Lack of staff, due to sickness but then that can't be helped.

review_title: Worked in head office in London
pros: Most people are so friendly and great to work with - people really go the extra mile. It's an inspirational place to work, the programmes and services they deliver to people are great. The pension, health scheme and discount scheme is good too.
cons:
Sadly, lots. The learning and development is awful, which I think has led to very poor management in head office. There's lots of talk of honesty and transparency but in practice I rarely saw this. There are a couple of  fantastic leaders who genuinely want to improve things and treat people fairly - the head of HR being one. But others are ruthless and shouldn't be in the charity sector.
Also no sick pay is appalling, especially when it's a disability charity!

review_title: Some good opportunities but turbulence in senior management and a lack of quality leadership
pros: Pay is better than many comparable organisations, at least in head office. Sheer size of the organisation offers some scope for new opportunities.
cons: Overly political in many parts of the organisation. Lack of quality leadership. Some people don't take the work as seriously as they should.

pros:
- Worked in a lovely team 
- Working directly with service users was rewarding
cons:
- Poor senior management and vision 
- Constant change, very unsteady environment 
- Disconnect between care homes and London employees
- Lack of integration of remote working staff 
- Severe lack of personal development despite large charity status
- Very poor transparency, no open door policies
- Bullying tactics from some senior management 
- Extremely poor sickness policy
- Watched charity handle disabled staff issues very poorly

review_title: Great cause but a few flaws.
pros:
Great cause, lovely people.
Go home at the end of the day feeling like you've done something positive.
cons:
Poor personal development opportunities.
Shocking sickness policy - for a disability charity it's ridiculous. Also the maternity policy is equally bad.
Outdated expectation that being at your desk 9-5pm is the best way to work.
Huge disconnect between head office and services.
Very little trust in senior management - many people feel uncertain.

pros: The only positive was the group of carers I worked with
cons:
This hides behind the title of charity, its a business that only cares about the money they can charge to residents in their homes.
They do not care a jot about the staff at the bottom of the pile the ones that work 14 hour shifts taking physical and verbal abuse from some residents because they want to money so they don't say no to challenging behaviour residents despite them causing problems to other residents. Staff don't matter they are treated like work horses for rubbish pay.
They are paid just above minimum age when the the top job is paid a six figure wage. STAY AWAY PEOPLE.

pros: It has changed my life! So much so I even live in the house in the grounds. Welcoming, friendly, so rewarding, amazing staff and residents, eye opening, range of activities for all are immense. I truly love this job this place this company.
cons: It is completely impossible to not get a bond with your residents, making it difficult when anything happens.

pros: I love my job and the residents , making a change to their lives , helping them and encouraging them and most of all putting a smile on their face .
cons: To many agency and pushy care supervisors , who work you to hard .

pros: Was okay in the beginning, nothing to scream and shout about.  Relatively good standard of care given to clients.  One team lead is fab, there for you in a pinch, However....
cons:
Constantly employing agency over the past few months, to the point clients are upset and feeling uneasy with the constant change of staff- zero continuity provided.  
Staff are being cut left, right and centre.  Less staff on shift at a time but more clients recently arrived.  
Unrealistic demands for the lack of staff, expected to meet everyones care time allowance however a single support worker is split between two tenants, sometimes more if there is a lack of meds trained workers on the floor.  
Pay, Well thats a whole new level of shocking.  Not only is care work shifts (happy with this for a price) the pay is absolutely rubbish.  No I am not in care for the money however to be able to provide care you must be able to sustain yourself, on this pay its hard.  The night staff also get the same pay as days (I'd never work such unsociable hours for nothing in return.  
Never feel safe in work as there is a real 'blame' culture here.  Those who raise concerns are made out to be at fault constantly.
Many staff haven't met the new manager in the 3-4 months she has been here.  Big concern amongst staff being that she is changing staffing levels/care plans etc but has not worked the floor more then a few times (too few staff situations- can not get off the floor fast enough)  
Staff have also been told contracted hours are to change to working an hour earlier or later (7 am starts or 11 pm finishes)- there goes staffs social and home lives- doesn't effect managers/team leads as they can stick to their 9 am starts and swanning off as and when they please.  
As one can tell from this little summary, the care is not for staff nor client but for those in the office doing as they please for who they please as treatment standards differ amongst staff HUGELY!

review_title: A stable employer with a worthwhile mission.
